questions.text: A 53-year-old male presented with a history of post-prandial fullness of the abdomen. CT scan revealed a retroperitoneal mass with intra-abdominal extension. Perioperatively there was a large mesenteric tumor infiltrating the greater omentum. Tumor was resected. There was a gray-brown/tan nodule in the omentum measuring 2x 1cm. On Microscopic examination, the Gray brown nodule in the omentum showed a well-formed capsule, trabeculae, red pulp, and white pulp of the spleen and was diagnosed as splenunculi. The most common site for splenunculi in descending order of frequency is:

options.label: A
options.text: Gastrocolic Ligament, the Pancreatic Tail, the Greater Omentum.

options.label: B
options.text: Gastrocolic Ligament, the Greater Omentum, Hilum of the Spleen.

options.label: C
options.text: Hilum of the Spleen, the Greater Omentum, the Pancreatic Tail

options.label: D
options.text: Hilum of the Spleen, the Pancreatic Tail, the Greater Omentum

questions.correct_answer: D. Hilum of the Spleen, the Pancreatic Tail, the Greater Omentum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hilum of the Spleen, the Pancreatic Tail, the Greater Omentum Over 80 % of accessory spleens are found in the region of the splenic hilum and vascular pedicle . Other locations for accessory spleens in descending order of frequency are the gastrocolic ligament, the pancreas tail, the greater omentum, the stomach’s greater curve, the splenocolic ligament, the small and large bowel mesentery, the left broad ligament in women, and the left spermatic cord in men.

Highyeild:

The most common anomaly in splenic embryology is the presence of accessory spleens. Accessory spleens are present in approximately 20% of the population. Up to 30% of patients with the hematologic disease may have one or more accessory spleens. Over 80% of accessory spleens are located in the region of the splenic hilum and vascular pedicle.

Locations for accessory spleens in descending order of frequency are the hilum of the spleen, gastrocolic ligament, the pancreas tail, the greater omentum, the stomach’s greater curve, the splenocolic ligament, the small and large bowel mesentery, the left broad ligament in women, and the left spermatic cord in men. Option: B. Locations for accessory spleens in descending order of frequency are the hilum of the spleen, gastrocolic ligament, the pancreas tail, the greater omentum, the stomach’s greater curve, the splenocolic ligament, the small and large bowel mesentery, the left broad ligament in women, and the left spermatic cord in men. Option: C . Locations for accessory spleens in descending order of frequency are the hilum of the spleen, gastrocolic ligament, the pancreas tail, the greater omentum, the stomach’s greater curve, the splenocolic ligament, the small and large bowel mesentery, the left broad ligament in women, and the left spermatic cord in men.

questions.text: Identify the most common location of the accessory spleen from the given image which is marked as follows:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Splenunculi are single or multiple accessory spleens that are found in approximately 10–30% of the population. They are located near the hilum of the spleen (A) in 50% of cases.

Highyeild:

Splenunculi are accessory spleens that are found in a significant portion of the population ( 10-30% ). These small, spherical, or ovoid bodies resemble the structure and function of the spleen but are separate from the main spleen. Splenunculi can be located in various areas of the abdomen, but are most commonly found near the hilum of the spleen . In some cases, splenunculi may be discovered incidentally during an imaging study or surgical procedure, and many people may never know they have them. Splenunculi are generally considered to be benign and do not typically require treatment unless they cause complications such as abdominal pain or obstruction.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Accessory spleens can be located near the pancreas tail in 6% of the population. Option: C . Accessory spleens can be located near the splenocolic ligament in 2% of the population. Option: D . Accessory spleens can be located near the mesentery in 0.5% of the population.

questions.text: A 47‐year‐old man was rushed to the hospital in a state of severe hypovolaemic shock and a distended abdomen. On presentation to the hospital he was hypotensive at 74/50 mm Hg, and tachycardic with a pulse of 122 beats/min. Abdominal examination was unremarkable. A bedside ultrasound scan revealed large amounts of intraperitoneal fluid. At subsequent laparotomy, 4 liters of blood was found in the abdomen and the source was from the splenic artery. A splenectomy was performed along with ligation of the splenic artery. Which of the following is true regarding splenic artery aneurysm?

options.label: A
options.text: They are twice as common among men

options.label: B
options.text: Most common site is the main arterial trunk

options.label: C
options.text: Splenic artery aneurysms are usually found in more than one site.

options.label: D
options.text: The aneurysm is usually symptomless unless it ruptures.

questions.correct_answer: D. The aneurysm is usually symptomless unless it ruptures.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The aneurysm is usually symptomless unless it ruptures. The splenic artery aneurysm is usually symptomless unless it ruptures and is more likely to be detected on a plain abdominal radiograph or scan.

Highyeild:

The most common site of intra-abdominal aneurysm is the aorta, followed by the splenic artery. The splenic artery is the most common site of splanchnic artery aneurysms. Arteriosclerosis is the most common cause of splenic artery aneurysms. Splenic artery aneurysms are usually saccular, and multiple aneurysms are present in 20% of cases. Calcification is present in approximately one-third of cases and is mostly located in the distal third of the splenic artery. Splenic artery aneurysms are four times more common in women, with possible contributing factors such as multiparity, portal hypertension, arterial fibrodysplasia, pancreatitis, trauma, arteritis, and septic emboli. Aneurysmal rupture during pregnancy typically occurs during the third trimester. Factors that increase the risk of rupture include young age, absence of aneurysmal calcification, presence of hypertension, and an aneurysm diameter greater than 1.5 cm.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Splenic artery aneurysms are four times more common in women. Option: B. A most common site of the splenic artery aneurysm is the main arterial trunk. Option: C. Splenic artery aneurysms are generally single. More than one aneurysm is found in one-quarter of cases.

Extraedge:

Documented aneurysmal enlargement and symptoms caused by the aneurysm are indications for surgery. An aneurysm detected in a woman who anticipates pregnancy should be removed, and one detected during pregnancy should be removed before the third trimester. Proximal aneurysms are excised after proximal and distal ligations. Mid-splenic aneurysms are excluded by proximal and distal ligations of the splenic artery and all collateral vessels. The most common type of splenic artery aneurysm, the distal or hilar aneurysm, is treated with aneurysmectomy and splenectomy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old lady presented with complaints of severe epigastric abdominal pain. On examination, her heart rate was 110/min and her blood pressure was 90/50 mmHg. Her abdomen was distended with mild general tenderness. The patient was later diagnosed with a splenic artery aneurysm. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of splenic artery aneurysm?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement is more commonly undertaken to better characterize the nature of the suspected splenic pathology and to exclude other intra-abdominal pathology and is the investigation of choice for splenic artery aneurysm.

Highyeild:

An aneurysm is usually asymptomatic until it ruptures and can be detected through radiographs or scans. A bruit may be present, but the aneurysm is unlikely to be palpable. A ruptured aneurysm mimics symptoms of splenic rupture and is often unexpected. Younger patients and pregnant women are at a higher risk of experiencing a rupture, with almost inevitable fetal death in pregnant women. Treatment options include embolization or endovascular stenting following selective splenic artery angiography.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Ultrasound is rapid, relatively easy to perform, and is often the first imaging modality used to evaluate the spleen in a trauma patient. Ultrasonography can be used to determine the size and consistency of the spleen, and whether a cyst is present. Option: C . MRI can be a valuable adjunct to the more commonly used imaging techniques when the splenic disease is suspected but offers no obvious advantage for primary imaging of the spleen. Option: D . Plain Radiography is rarely used for primary splenic imaging but the incidental finding of calcification of the splenic artery or spleen may raise the possible diagnosis of a splenic artery aneurysm

Extraedge:

For younger patients with an asymptomatic splenic artery aneurysm, surgery or interventional radiolog y is recommended after a CT scan, MRI, or selective coeliac angiography confirms the diagnosis. Observation may be the preferred treatment option for elderly patients with a calcified aneurysm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female was admitted to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain which began two hours ago after blunt abdominal trauma. Her pulse was 70 beats/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm/Hg, and body temperature was 36.5°C. On abdominal examination, the abdomen was distended, bowel sounds were normal, and she had left upper quadrant tenderness. Which of the following will be the first investigation if splenic rupture is suspected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ultrasound Ultrasound is rapid, relatively easy to perform, and is often the first imaging modality used to evaluate the spleen in a trauma patient. Ultrasonography can be used to determine the size and consistency of the spleen, and whether a cyst is present.

Highyeild:

Plain radiology is not commonly used for diagnosis. Incidental findings of calcification in the splenic artery or spleen may suggest various conditions such as splenic artery aneurysm, old infarct, benign cyst, or hydatid disease. Multiple calcifications may suggest splenic tuberculosis. Ultrasonography can provide information on spleen size and consistency, as well as the presence of cysts. Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement is commonly used to better understand the nature of suspected splenic pathologies and exclude other intra-abdominal issues. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be useful, especially for distinguishing cystic lesions through T2-weighted images.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement is more commonly undertaken to better characterize the nature of the suspected splenic pathology and to exclude other intra-abdominal pathology and is the investigation of choice for splenic artery aneurysm. However; it requires that the patient to be hemodynamically stable. Option: C . MRI can be a valuable adjunct to the more commonly used imaging techniques when the splenic disease is suspected but offers no obvious advantage for primary imaging of the spleen. Option: D . Plain Radiography is rarely used for primary splenic imaging but the incidental finding of calcification of the splenic artery or spleen may raise the possible diagnosis of a splenic artery aneurysm. CT scan is the investigation of choice for splenic artery aneurysm.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for splenectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura The usual first line of therapy in Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura is oral prednisone at a dosage of 1.0 to 1.5 mg/kg per day. Splenectomy is selectively indicated for the failure of medical therapy, for prolonged use of steroids with undesirable effects, and in selected cases after the first relapse.

Highyeild:

ITP is caused by antibodies to specific platelet membrane glycoproteins. It results in isolated thrombocytopenia , and can be acute or chronic. Acute ITP usually resolves spontaneously , while chronic ITP persists for longer than 6 months without a specific cause being identified. Clinical features include purpuric patches on the skin and mucous membranes, spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes, and menorrhagia in women. Diagnosis is indicated by the presence of cutaneous ecchymoses and a positive tourniquet test. Investigations involve normal coagulation studies and a reduced platelet count in the peripheral blood film. Treatment involves short courses of corticosteroids , which are usually followed by recovery. Splenectomy is usually recommended for refractory or relapsing ITP, with up to two-thirds of patients being cured by surgical intervention. Laparoscopic splenectomy is becoming the mainstay of treatment. In the acute setting, fresh blood transfusion or transfusion with platelet concentrates may be necessary before the Operation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Treatment of AIHA depends on the severity of the disease and whether it is primary or secondary. The mainstay treatment for both primary and secondary forms of symptomatic, unstable AIHA remains long term corticosteroid administration.36 Therapy should continue until a response is noted by a rise in hematocrit and fall in reticulocyte count, which generally occurs within 3 weeks. Option: B. The mainstay of therapy in Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency is avoidance of drugs known to precipitate hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency. Transfusions are given in cases of symptomatic anemia. Option: D . None of the above can not be the correct option.

What is the treatment for Refractory cases of ITP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenectomy Splenectomy is selectively indicated for the failure of medical therapy, for prolonged use of steroids with undesirable effects, and in selected cases after the first relapse. Splenectomy is an effective option for refractory ITP and provides a permanent response without the subsequent need for steroids in 75% to 85% of patients.

However, splenectomy is considered as the definitive treatment for refractory cases of ITP. Option: B. If corticosteroids are not effective, other treatments such as intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasma exchange can be considered. questions.text: A splenic artery aneurysm was diagnosed in a 24-year-old female. Which of the following is an indication for surgical treatment of a splenic aneurysm?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pregnancy Splenic artery aneurysm (SAA) is four times more common among women than men. SAA is particularly worrisome when discovered during pregnancy, as rupture imparts a high risk of mortality to both mother (70%) and the foetus (95%). Indications for treatment include the presence of symptoms, pregnancy, intention to become pregnant, and pseudoaneurysms associated with inflammatory processes.

The most common site of intra-abdominal aneurysm is the aorta, followed by the splenic artery. The splenic artery is the most common site of splanchnic artery aneurysms. Aneurysmal rupture during pregnancy typically occurs during the third trimester. Factors that increase the risk of rupture include young age, absence of aneurysmal calcification, presence of hypertension, and an aneurysm diameter greater than 1.5 cm.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presented with a productive cough, shortness of breath, and decreased appetite for 4 days. Initial clinical assessment revealed signs of consolidation in the right lower lobe. She had normal heart sounds, a palpable but non-tender spleen, and was febrile. Investigations undertaken showed a large splenic abscess measuring 9.6×8.2×7.9 cm. Which is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of a splenic abscess?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement is more commonly undertaken to better characterize the nature of the suspected splenic pathology and to exclude other intra-abdominal pathology and is the investigation of choice for splenic abscess. CT is the preferred method for diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Splenic abscess is a rare but potentially life-threatening illness with a mortality rate that ranges from 15-20% in previously healthy patients with single unilocular lesions to 80% for multiple abscesses in immunocompromised patients. The predisposing factors for splenic abscess include malignancies, polycythemia vera, endocarditis, prior trauma, hemoglobinopathies, urinary tract infections, IV drug use, and AIDS. About 70% of splenic abscesses result from the spread of infective organisms from another location through the bloodstream, such as in endocarditis, osteomyelitis, and IV drug use. Gram-positive cocci (especially Staphylococcus ), Streptococcus, Enterococcus species, and gram-negative enteric organisms are usually involved in splenic abscesses. Salmonella, Enterobacter species, and other enteric organisms are common in splenic abscesses in patients with sickle cell anemia. Fungal abscesses , such as those caused by Candida spp, occur mostly in immunosuppressed patients.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Ultrasound is rapid, relatively easy to perform, and is often the first imaging modality used to evaluate the spleen in a trauma patient. Ultrasonography can be used to determine the size and consistency of the spleen, and whether a cyst is present. However, the diagnosis can also be made with ultrasound. Option: C . MRI can be a valuable adjunct to the more commonly used imaging techniques when the splenic disease is suspected but offers no obvious advantage for primary imaging of the spleen. Option: D . Plain radiography is rarely used for primary splenic imaging but can be used for the finding of calcification of the splenic artery.

Extraedge:

Splenic abscesses are usually present with nonspecific symptoms such as vague abdominal pain, fever, peritonitis, and pleuritic chest pain. Splenomegaly is not typical. CT is the diagnostic tool of choice for splenic abscesses, but ultrasound can also be used for diagnosis. Treatment for unilocular abscesses typically involves percutaneous drainage and antibiotics, with success rates ranging from 75-90%. For multilocular lesions, splenectomy, drainage of the left upper quadrant, and antibiotics are required.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman during her ultrasound for pregnancy was found to have a calcified 1cm mass in the epigastrium. A bruit was heard in the epigastric region. She does not have any symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenic artery aneurysm This pregnant woman has the incidental finding of a splenic artery aneurysm . These are usually silent unless they rupture. Fifty percent of cases of rupture occur in patients younger than 45 years, and 25% occur in pregnant women usually in the third trimester or during labor.

Highyeild:

SAA is more common in women than men , and during pregnancy, the risk of rupture is higher due to hormonal changes, increased blood flow, and pressure on the splenic artery by the growing uterus. The risk of mortality for both mother and fetus is high if SAA ruptures during pregnancy, and hence, surgical intervention is essential. Indications for surgical treatment of SAA in pregnancy include the presence of symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever, intention to become pregnant, and pseudoaneurysms associated with inflammatory processes. Surgery during pregnancy is challenging and requires a multidisciplinary approach involving obstetricians, vascular surgeons, and anesthesiologists. Open surgery and endovascular techniques can be used for treating SAA during pregnancy. The choice of surgical technique depends on the size, location, and type of aneurysm . Open surgery involves laparotomy or splenectomy, and it is associated with a higher risk of complications, longer hospital stays, and recovery time. Endovascular techniques include coil embolization, stent grafting, and balloon occlusion. These procedures are less invasive and have a shorter recovery time but are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. The timing of surgery depends on the gestational age, stability of the mother and fetus, and the urgency of the surgical intervention. Surgery is usually performed in the second trimester when the risk to the fetus is relatively low. Postoperative management includes close monitoring of the mother and fetus, pain control, prophylaxis against thromboembolic events, and management of any complications.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Splenic rupture should be considered in any case of blunt abdominal trauma, particularly when the injury occurs to the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Option: C .Clinical manifestations of splenic abscess include fever, left upper quadrant pain, leukocytosis, and splenomegaly in about one-third of patients. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound or CT scan. Option: D . Clinical manifestations of splenic cysts generally are related to the presence of a mass lesion in the left upper quadrant or a lesion that impinges on the stomach. Ultrasound can establish the presence of a cystic lesion and occasionally incidentally detect asymptomatic lesions as well. Serologic testing for echinococcal antibodies can confirm or exclude the cystic lesion as parasitic, an important piece of information when planning operative therapy. Symptomatic parasitic cysts are best treated with splenectomy.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman was a pedestrian hit by a car while crossing the road. She complains of the chest and abdominal pains. On examination, her GCS score is 14/15 (E4, V4, M6). Her vital observations are as follows: BP 86/32 mmHg; pulse 145/min. She has bruising and tenderness over her lower left 9th and 10th ribs. She has rebound tenderness and guarding over the left upper quadrant of her abdomen. Her chest X-ray demonstrates left rib fractures affecting ribs 8–10. Select the likely diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ruptured spleen This patient is presenting with a ruptured spleen (left lower rib fractures with associated hypotension) secondary to trauma. Splenic rupture should be considered in any case of blunt abdominal trauma, particularly when the injury occurs to the left upper quadrant of the abdomen Patients present with abdominal pain, left shoulder tip pain (Kehr’s sign), hypotension, and tachycardia. Bruising may present over the left upper abdomen, left chest, or left lower back and is associated with underlying hemorrhage. TOC in unstable pt is splenectomy.

Highyeild:

The spleen is the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organ due to blunt abdominal trauma. Iatrogenic injury to the spleen is a frequent complication of surgical procedures, particularly those in the left upper quadrant when adhesions are present. Splenic rupture is classified into five grades based on the extent of the injury as seen on a CT scan. Vigorous resuscitation is crucial in managing blunt trauma. Splenectomy is recommended for severe grades of injury where controlling bleeding takes priority over attempts to salvage the spleen. Splenic angiography with embolization may be an alternative to splenectomy, but should not delay surgery in a hemodynamically unstable patient. Rupture of an enlarged spleen due to malaria is not uncommon in tropical countries and may present with delayed symptoms following a minor injury. Radiological embolization may be performed in such cases if available, but splenectomy should be considered before a peri splenic hematoma ruptures. Surgery in such patients is challenging, and early ligation of the splenic vessels along the superior border of the pancreatic body should be considered before disturbing the hematoma.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Findings that suggest tension pneumothorax include unequal breath sounds (diminished or absent on the side of the pneumothorax), tracheal deviation (away from the side of the pneumothorax), distended neck veins, and/or signs of respiratory distress. Option: B. The classic signs in cardiac tamponade are included in Beck's triad of hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. Option: C . The aneurysm is symptomless unless it ruptures and is more likely to be detected on a plain abdominal radiograph or scan. It is unlikely to be palpable, although a bruit may be present.

questions.text: Findings of enlarged spleen was found on ultrasound of a 28-year-old female. An abdominal CT confirmed the presence of a splenic cyst at the lower pole of the spleen 7 cm in diameter, no with other organ involvement. Which of the following is the most common etiology of splenic cysts worldwide?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parasitic infection Parasitic infection is the most common cause of splenic cysts worldwide, and the majority are due to the Echinococcus species.

Highyeild:

Splenic cysts can be categorized based on different criteria, with one clinically relevant scheme being parasitic vs. nonparasitic true splenic cysts. Parasitic infections, particularly those caused by Echinococcus species, are the most common cause of splenic cysts worldwide. Symptoms of parasitic cysts are generally related to the presence of a mass lesion in the left upper quadrant or a lesion that impinges on the stomach. Ultrasound can establish the presence of a cystic lesion and occasionally incidentally detect asymptomatic lesions. Serologic testing for echinococcal antibodies can confirm or exclude the cystic lesion as parasitic, which is important information for planning operative therapy. Splenectomy is the preferred treatment for symptomatic parasitic cysts. Precautions should be taken during surgery to avoid spillage of cyst contents into the peritoneal cavity to prevent the possibility of anaphylactic shock, although this is rare.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A .The non-parasitic cysts are further divided into true cysts and pseudocysts. True cysts are lined with epithelium and may be considered congenital. They account for 10% of all splenic cysts. Option: B . Cysts resulting from trauma are termed pseudocysts due to their lack of an epithelial cell lining. Option: D . Nonparasitic true cysts of the spleen account for approximately 10% of all splenic cysts.

Extraedge:

Pseudocysts are splenic cysts that result from trauma and do not have an epithelial cell lining. Nonparasitic true splenic cysts can also be dermoid, epidermoid, or epithelial in nature. Asymptomatic nonparasitic cysts may be observed with close follow-up by ultrasound, while large cysts managed nonoperatively pose a risk of rupture with even minor abdominal trauma. Small symptomatic nonparasitic cysts may be excised with splenic preservation, and large symptomatic nonparasitic cysts may be unroofed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with complaints of abdominal pain which was worsening. The abdominal CT revealed a large amount of free fluid in the abdomen. The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy for assessment of a perforated viscus. Upon opening the abdomen, 1,400 mL of fresh blood was removed. The source of the bleeding was determined to be a ruptured spleen. The spleen was removed without complication and was sent for pathological investigation. What is the most common complication following open splenectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left lower lobe atelectasis Traumatic rupture of the spleen continues as the most common indication for Open Splenectomy. Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after Open Splenectomy, and typically occurs 2-3 days after Sx.

Highyeild:

Immediate complications specific to splenectomy include hemorrhage resulting from a slipped ligature. Left basal atelectasis is common, and pleural effusion may be present. Adjacent structures at risk during the procedure include the stomach and pancreas. Damage to the greater curvature of the stomach during ligation of the short gastric vessels may result in a fistula . Damage to the tail of the pancreas during ligation of the splenic vessels at the hilum may result in pancreatitis , a localized abscess, or a pancreatic fistula. Postoperative thrombocytosis may arise, and prophylactic aspirin is recommended if the blood platelet count exceeds 1 × 106/mL. Long-term surveillance programs have emphasized an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The risk of pneumonia, meningitis, and major sepsis following splenectomy is increased threefold. Opportunistic postsplenectomy infection (OPSI) is a major concern. Measures to prevent infections after splenectomy include appropriate and timely immunization, antibiotic prophylaxis, education, and prompt treatment of infection.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A .Pancreatitis, pseudocyst, and pancreatic fistula are among the pancreatic complications that may result from intraoperative trauma to the pancreas during dissection of the splenic hilum. Option: C .Hemorrhage can occur intraoperatively or postoperatively, presenting as a subphrenic hematoma. Option: D .Subphrenic abscess and wound infection are among the perioperative infectious complications.

Extraedge:

Vaccination against pneumococcus, meningococcus C, and H. influenzae type b is recommended. Asplenic patients should carry a medical alert and an up-to-date vaccination card. Vaccination can be given in the postoperative period following splenectomy for trauma, but protection following vaccination is not always guaranteed.

questions.text: Splenectomy was planned for a 27-year-old female after the incidental finding of the splenic cyst. Regarding the recommendation for elective splenectomy, which of the following is considered to be true?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every year)

options.label: B
options.text: Vaccinating against H. Influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years)

options.label: D
options.text: Children who have undergone splenectomy before the age of 5 years should be treated with a daily dose of penicillin until the age of 18 years.

questions.correct_answer: B. Vaccinating against H. Influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vaccinating against H. Influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) If elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years).

Highyeild:

Splenectomy is only recommended for ITP (immune thrombocytopenia) patients who have failed medical therapy, have been on prolonged steroid treatment with negative side effects, or in certain cases after the first relapse. The term "prolonged use of steroids" may vary, but typically refers to a need for more than 10-20 mg/d for 3-6 months to maintain a platelet count of greater than 30,000/mm3. Referral for splenectomy is typically prompted by the persistent need for high-dose steroids. Splenectomy is a successful treatment option for refractory ITP, providing a permanent response without the need for subsequent steroid treatment in 75%-85% of patients. Laparoscopic techniques have been reviewed in recent meta-analyses to assess the global results of splenectomy for ITP.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A .If elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years). Option: C . Yearly influenza vaccination has been recommended, as there is some evidence that it may reduce the risk of secondary bacterial infection. Such vaccinations should be administered at least 2 weeks before elective surgery or as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital. Option: D . Children who have undergone splenectomy before the age of 5 years should be treated with a daily dose of penicillin until the age of 10 years. Prophylaxis in older children should be continued at least until the age of 16 years, but its use is less well-defined in adults.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a 3-day history of abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, he was pyrexic at 38.4 °C with mild tachycardia at 100–105 bpm. The abdomen was distended with fullness, tenderness, and guarding especially over the left upper quadrant. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen revealed a 15-cm cystic lesion arising from the lower pole of the mildly enlarged spleen at its widest diameter with rim calcification suggesting that the cyst had been present for a long time. Despite a trial of intravenous antibiotics, he remained pyrexial and a decision was made for exploratory laparotomy. The infected part of the spleen was then transected. Which of the following organism is involved in the development of post-splenectomy septicaemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Postsplenectomy septicaemia may result from Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides, Haemophilus influenzae, and Escherichia coli. Published guidelines emphasize that most infections after splenectomy could be avoided through measures that include offering patients appropriate and timely immunization, antibiotic prophylaxis, education, and prompt treatment of infection.

Highyeild:

Postsplenectomy sepsis can occur after spleen removal. Bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Escherichia coli can cause postsplenectomy sepsis. The risk of pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis following splenectomy is increased threefold in the long term. Age, chemoradiotherapy treatment, and underlying conditions like thalassemia, sickle cell disease, autoimmune anemia, or thrombocytopenia can further increase the risk of postsplenectomy sepsis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Postsplenectomy septicaemia may result from Streptococcus pneumonia. Option: B .Postsplenectomy septicaemia may result from Neisseria meningitides. Option: C .Postsplenectomy septicaemia may result from Haemophilus influenza.

questions.text: Ultrasound examination on a 21-year-old male indicated an irregular hyperechoic area with indistinguishable boundaries in the spleen. On a contrast-enhanced CT scan, a tumor presented a gradual light-to-moderate level of contrast enhancement. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed abnormal signal density in the splenic parenchyma with heterogeneous hypointensity. Multiple small, round, low-density lesions and splenomegaly were observed. The patient was diagnosed with splenic tumors, and a laparoscopic splenectomy was performed. Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the spleen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Haemangioma Haemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the spleen.

Highyeild:

The most common benign tumor of the spleen is splenic hemangioma. Splenic hemangiomas are vascular tumors that arise from blood vessels in the spleen. Most splenic hemangiomas are small and asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally during imaging studies. In rare cases, splenic hemangiomas can cause abdominal pain or discomfort. Treatment of splenic hemangiomas may require surgical removal of the spleen. Other types of benign tumors can occur in the spleen, but splenic hemangiomas are the most common.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Lymphoma is the most common tumor involving the spleen. Option: C. Haemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the spleen and may rarely develop into a hemangiosarcoma that is managed by splenectomy. Angiosarcomas (or hemangiosarcomas) of the spleen usually occur spontaneously but have been linked to environmental exposures, such as thorium dioxide and monomeric vinyl chloride. Option: D . Lymphangiomas are endothelium-lined cysts and are usually benign tumors; however, lymphangiosarcoma has been found within lymphangiomas.
